subject: RE: [junit] Testing SQL: was Test-first paper
msgSnippet: SQLJ for Oracle 8.1.7 catches bad column names with no problems.  Did you alter the connect.properties file to connect to the database, or use the -user
messageBody:
SQLJ for Oracle 8.1.7 catches bad column names with no problems. Did you
alter the connect.properties file to connect to the database, or use the
-user command line option?

Donald Holliday


-----Original Message-----
From: Neil Swingler [mailto:nswingler@...]
Sent: Thursday, September 27, 2001 2:28 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Testing SQL: was Test-first paper


We used to use SQLJ for oracle and it didn't catch bad column names.
In the end it didn't seem to be that much of an improvement over
JDBC to introduce another kind of source file.

-- Neil Swingler

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Holliday, Donald B. (LNG-SHEP) [mailto:dhollida@...]
> Sent: 26 September 2001 17:42
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing SQL: was Test-first paper
>
>
> <snip>Surely the only way to test SQL is to use a database.</snip>
>
> But the best way to test syntax before you even run a test is to use SQLJ
> along with a database connection and have it check syntax, table
> names, and
> column names. This eliminates all errors SQL except logic errors.
>
